answers.answer: If they thought your kidneys were in the least bit compromised they would not give you contrast dye. There is a combination of things together which would send off a red flag. Tests are indicators it takes a doctor who knows what medications you are on and your over all health to make an assessment.Mine are high but the doctor tells me that my blood work is great.You probably should talk to a financial planner. I went to a free seminar our local NMSS had with a finacial planner. I would not know what to tell you.Alex

Thanks, Alex.  I am very concerned about the dye and have no idea why my tests results were ignored.  I am quite upset a little it this because I am dizzy and very short of breath.  I don't know why the nurse is dismissing this problem, too.  I can't get in to see my GP tomorrow.  I will have to take off from work Monday or Tuesday to ask him all of these questions.  The more I read, the more scary this is.  My test results show stage 3- moderate kidney dysfunction and this was before the MRI and dye and before I became violently ill, took a toxic over the counter medicine for the kidneys and got very dehydrated.I will look for my local NMSS.  I have never thought about this because this came up so quickly.  I never thought I may (could be jumping to conclusions) with chronic kidney disease.I am wondering if the gladolium caused problems with my kidneys in the first place.
Hi Deb -Gadolinium can be a problem for people with compromised kidney function, and chronic bladder problems can cause kidney issues. I would discuss your results and concerns with your PCP.Kyle

Thanks, Kyle.  I couldn't get in today to see the doctor as the office was closed.  it doesn't make any sense to give a test for kidney function before the dye is given, only to ignore the abnormal results.

question: I am sorry it's been so long!  It's been years!  MS is somewhat silent, but to my surprise I happened on irregular tests results taken before my MRI with enhancement.  To save time, I will copy and paste what I said in the kidney forum below; however, has anyone ever have abnormal creatinine and GFR tests?  Can an infection or dehydration cause those?  Can MS cause kidney problems from UTIs and bladder issues?  Do any of you have this problem?Here's the post:Hello, this is the first time to post in this forum.  I am a 53 yr. old female with multiple sclerosis and is overweight, but not obese, a history of high blood pressure, but is under good control.I went in for an MRI before Thamksgiving which included enhancement.  They do a screening for kidney problems prior to the MRI.  I never know the results.  They went ahead and did the test.  To my surprise, this time the results were posted online, and they were abnormal (which wasn't shared with my doctor).The GFR a was 47 and the creatinine was 1.20.  I wrote the doctor's office (MS Specialist) the nurse responded.  She said I shouldn't be concerned.  She said when I go in to see my GP at my yearly exam that I could mention this, if I wanted and that it wasn't a cause for alarm.  She said it was probably dehydration.What would cause these abnormal tests?  Can mild dehydration cause it?  Should I be concerned?Besides MS, these things may seem relevant:1) night sweats2)  shortness of breath (just started 2 days ago)3)  can't sleep4) on a seizure medicine- a generic of Klonopin5) taking Provigil for fatigue6) low vitamin D (for quite some- said not unusual for people with MS), but is normal now with 3000 units of vit D daily7) history of many UTI due to problems emptying bladder thought to be from MS8) urinary incontinence from MS9) urinary retention (thought to be from MS)10) hypothyroidism11) father died at 72 this year from stroke (related to diabetes).  My diabetes tests have been normal12) violently sick Sunday through Tuesday- well after tests results) with food poisoning (husband got same thing).  Right side of my back hurt very badly.  Took Aleve.  I have a hint of an ache there now, but this shortness of breath and dizziness has been a concern.Should I be worried?  I retiring this month and my retirement plan doesn't include caring for my husband if something was to happen to me to get my entire annuity (he's older than me and insisted to do it that way).  I am torn on whether to.change the plan to include him getting monthly annuity checks if I die before it's too late which will significantly lower my annuity.This sounds crazy, I know, but I have a lot on my plate!  I have only days from retirement.Thanks and sorry so longDebThanks MS Forum
title: Irregular Kidney Tests- Anyone ever Have This?
